channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for NH
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for NH

item.title: Report E-2025050463
item.description:
Report E-2025050463

Identified by scraper @ 2025-06-10T03:46:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-05-21
  • City: MANCHESTER
  • State: NH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On May 21, 2025, two (2) 5-gallon pails of paint were crushed in transit due to unprotected freight and released approximately five (5) gallons of paint to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Green Site Services Group (GSSG) to remediate the impacted site. The crew utilized granular absorbents and hand tools to collect the released product from the trailer interior. All impacted materials and the damaged pails were containerized in three (3) 55-gallon drums for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025050194
item.description:
Report E-2025050194

Identified by scraper @ 2025-06-10T03:46:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-04-11
  • City: MANCHESTER
  • State: NH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: AVELO AIRLINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Flight Attendants were just chimed for final descent into the Manchester Boston Regional Airport. Shortly after Customer noticed smoke coming from the side pocket of her backpack that was stowed underneath the seat in front of her. The Customer pulled the e-cigarette out of the backpack and tried to cover it as she went to the aft galley.Â  The device was hot to touch and had smoke coming from it. FA2 immediately notified the lead flight attendant, and then the lead notified the captain of the situation. Flight Attendants initially grabbed the Libik Kit but then decided as a group that given the phase of flight the best course of action was to submerge the device in water in the sink of the aft lav and locked the door. Lead Flight Attendant then notified the captain that the situation was under control and the device would continue to be monitored. Upon arrival at the gate Airport Ops was notified and device was handed over. No injuries were reported.
